tier.item: (5) Haitian CF (Lefebvre 1998:161; cited from Déchaine & Manfredi 1994)
Kenya Pidgin Swahili, for example, does not exhibit any traces of creolization, yet it has developed a
number of new functional categories (see Heine 1991).
For example, Saramaccan, which we classify here as an English-lexified creole could also be classified
As we will see below, however, the term intensifier, or its equivalents identifier, emphatic reflexive,
etc., raises problems since it simulatenously refers to a number of contrastive uses of one and the same

tier.item: Mo pu al lav mo latet
According to Carden & Stewart (1989:86), Negerhollands had only used [uR] plain pronouns, that is,
an A-reflexive throughout its known history.
This classification is based on Kouwenberg (1994:181), who says: "Reflexive pronouns are formed by
the combination of the possessive pronoun and selfu." But there is evidence to suggest that an AI-
Note, however, that Carden & Stewart (1989:86) argue that throughout its known history,
Negerhollands had only used [uR] plain pronouns, that is, an A-reflexive.
(a) 'I'll go wash myself', (b) 'I'll go wash my head'

Papiamentu CS there is overlap in that there are seven different forms that have replaced the Ibero-
